Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Influence of TiO2-500(A) calcination temperature (550 – 750 °C) on 10 wt%Ni in the hydrogenation of levulinic acid. Rutile TiO2 a desirable support for Ni catalyst in the synthesis of γ-valerolactone: Influence of titania crystal phase on the product distribution Shirisha Varimalla a b Sasikumar Boggala a Kalpana Manda a Padmasri Hari Aytam c Venugopal Akula a b ⁎ a Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Tarnaka, Hyderabad 500 007, Telangana, India Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Tarnaka Hyderabad Telangana 500 007 India Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Tarnaka, Hyderabad, TS, India – 500 007 b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, 201002, India. c Department of Chemistry, University College of Science, Osmania University, Hyderabad 500 007, Telangana, India Department of Chemistry, University College of Science, Osmania University Hyderabad Telangana 500 007 India Department of Chemistry, University College of Science, Osmania University, Hyderabad, TS, India – 500 007 ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Tarnaka, Hyderabad 500 007, Telangana, India. Department of Catalysis and Fine Chemicals, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Tarnaka Hyderabad Telangana 500 007 India Rutile TiO2 was identified as a suitable support for nickel than the anatase form in the selective conversion of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) with a 20-fold rate enhancement. TEM-HAADF results revealed a high degree of Ni encapsulation by titania species on the anatase that resulted in lower LA conversion with a high selectivity of angelica lactones. While nickel plateaus with protruding particles partially covered by TiOx overlayers on a rutile surface was the reason for the higher rate of GVL. CO chemisorption results indicated a lower uptake on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-anatase than on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-rutile catalyst and a high rate of hydrogen spillover was manifested by rutile TiO2 supported Ni catalyst than its counterpart anatase. Variations in the crystal phase of TiO2 and their interaction with nickel could substantially influence the GVL formation. High intrinsic activity of 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) was explained and discussed using surface and bulk characteristics of the catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Key words Ni-TiO2 interaction Titania migration Gamma-valerolactone H2-spillover TEM-HAADF Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Due to the depletion of non-renewable resources, R&D has focused on biomass as a carbon source for the production of fine chemicals and transportation fuels. Levulinic acid (LA), a biomass-derived compound, can be transformed into fuel additives and commodity chemicals [1]. Catalytic conversion of LA to fine chemicals such as angelica lactone (AL), γ-valerolactone (GVL), valeric acid (VA) and 2-methyl tetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF) has attracted much attention in the recent years due to their prominence in the oil, refinery and in the transportation sector [2]. LA can be hydrogenated to GVL through two distinct pathways; one involves its reduction to 4-hydroxyvaleric acid (4-HVA) followed by dehydration to GVL, and the other entails dehydration of LA to angelica lactone (AL) and then reduction to GVL [3]. Several homogeneous catalysts for the LA hydrogenation have been reported, e.g., Ru-based catalysts yielding high LA conversion and GVL selectivity [4]. The catalyst separation and recycling of the spent catalyst are somehow known barriers connected with these catalysts. LA has been hydrogenated over a number of heterogeneous catalysts utilizing molecular H2 or formic acid as the H-donor. Earlier we achieved a GVL rate of 15 × 10−6 mol h−1 (molRu)−1 at moderate temperature on Ru/HAP catalyst at 5 bar H2 pressure [5]. At 265 °C and 1 bar of H2 pressure, Upare & co-workers stated, LA conversion into 1,4 dioxane over commercial Ru/C, Pd/C, and Pt/C catalysts, which showed 98.6% selectivity [6]. The hydrogenation of LA with 2-sec-butyl phenol as a solvent using a Ru-Sn bimetallic system was reported by the Dumesic group at 180 °C and 35 bar H2 pressure [7]. The majority of reported studies on LA hydrogenation were carried out under elevated hydrogen pressures with noble-based metal catalysts and, in a few instances, non-ecofriendly solvents. Among the noble metals, supported Ru catalysts showed better activity in LA hydrogenation to GVL [7–14]. In contrast, the base metals, e.g., supported Ni catalysts, showed their prominence in the transformation of LA to GVL [5,15]. These Ni supported on conventional and non-conventional supports such as Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2, ZrO2 and zeolites demonstrated good LA conversions and > 90% selectivity towards GVL [16]. An important study reported by Kenichi et al. using TiO2 as a support that possesses largely (>95%) surface Lewis acidity had great impact on the product ratio during the LA conversion to GVL and VA [17,18]. TiO2 with different morphologies and varied structures have been identified as potential catalyst systems for solar energy conversion applications [19]. Qian et al. reported highly efficient 2D TiO2 nano-sheets for the electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction [20]. In a recent study Tian and co-workers developed TiO2 nano-belts for the photocatalytic antibacterial activity [21]. However, studies pertaining to interfacial sites appear to be involved in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL [22–24]. The influence of the TiO2 support phase (anatase, rutile, or a mixture of these two) on the Ni catalyst is not well explored for the transformation of LA to GVL. Studies on LA hydrogenation on the TiO2 supported metal catalysts, Luo et al. reported a GVL rate of 1.97 molGVL (gmetal)−1 h−1 over 1 wt% Au-Pd/TiO2 catalyst at 40 bar pressure [25] and about 98% GVL yields over 1 wt%Ru/TiO2 catalyst [26]. Exploring the calcium modified TiO2 supported Ru catalyst, Wojciechowska et al. demonstrated a GVL rate of 29 mmol (gcat)−1 h−1 using formic acid as a hydrogen source at 5 bar pressure [27]. Huang et al. examined the bimetallic Fe-Re supported TiO2 and achieved 95% of GVL yield at 40 bar [28]. Ruthenium supported on different shapes of TiO2, Li et al. excellent GVL yields at 30 bar pressure and room temperature conditions [29]. Most of these investigations were carried out in a batch process at elevated H2 pressures over metal supported on TiO2 catalysts. In this investigation we found rutile TiO2 as a facile support for nickel that showed tremendously higher rate of GVL ∼ 257 × 10−6 mol (gcat)−1 s−1. Hence, we made a detailed investigation on the role of TiO2 (anatase and rutile) supported Ni catalysts for the LA conversion and GVL rates. The as-synthesized TiO2 (anatase) sample was subjected to calcination at various temperatures (500–800 °C) to comprehend the role of anatase, rutile, and a mixture of these two supported Ni catalysts. For comparison purposes, a P25 (commercial TiO2 comprised of a mixture of anatase and rutile) denoted TiO2-P25 and a commercial anatase TiO2 was used as supports for Ni and examined with identical experimental conditions, for the process of LA hydrogenation. The hydrogenation activity of Ni supported on rutile-TiO2 was 20-fold higher than that of anatase-TiO2. The rationale behind the typical behavior of Ni supported on different TiO2 phases (anatase, rutile, and a mixture of anatase and rutile) was examined and discussed for the hydrogenation of LA in conjunction with bulk, surface properties of these catalysts (fresh, some of which were reduced and used) characterized by using various techniques, details are given in [SI]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6 H2O), levulinic acid (LA; 98%), α-angelica lactone (AL; 98%) titanium-tetra isopropoxide, isopropanol and γ-valerolactone (GVL; 99%) procured from Sigma-Aldrich (analytical grade), utilized without undergoing further purification. Deionized water was utilized for the catalyst's preparation. The TiO2-Anatase (denoted as TiO2-A) was obtained by calcining the as-synthesized TiO2 sample at 500 °C. The TiO2 Degussa-P25 (BET-surface area = 50.7 m2 g−1 containing both anatase and rutile phases) and a commercial anatase TiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, BET-SA = 15.8 m2 g−1) were used as supports as such. The TiO2-A was calcined in air subjected to varying temperatures ranging from 500° to 800°C for 5 h which are denoted as TiO2-500(A), TiO2-550(A, R), TiO2-650(R, A), TiO2-A750(R, A), and TiO2-800(R), and were used as supports. 2.2 Preparation of Ni supported on TiO2 catalysts The TiO2 was synthesized following the procedure reported earlier [30]. A loading of 10 wt%Ni is fixed for the preparation of the catalysts. To facilitate comparison, the commercial TiO2-P25 and anatase TiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich) were prepared using impregnation technique. In a standard procedure, needed amount of aqueous Ni(NO3)2. 6 H2O solution was mixed with a desired amount of solid support material subjected to continuous stirring at 100 °C until the water was evaporated, then oven dried at 120 °C for 12 h before being calcination was performed in static air at 500 °C for 5 h to produce a nominal 10 wt% Ni on respective supports. The actual Ni loadings confirmed by ICP-OES are found to be around 10 wt% with ± 0.2 wt% Ni [Table S1]. Powder XRD analysis indicated that the TiO2-P25 sample displayed both rutile, anatase and the commercial TiO2 showed anatase phase only. The TiO2 subjected to calcination at 500 °C, exhibited reflections due to anatase peaks only while the TiO2 calcined at 800 °C showed exclusively the rutile phase, hence, hereafter, these samples are denoted as TiO2-500(A) and TiO2-800(R) respectively. Remaining samples are denoted with respect to their calcination temperatures (550 −750 °C) as all of these were composed of both anatase and rutile TiO2 phases e.g., the TiO2 calcined at 550 °C is noted as TiO2-550(A, R) and the same for TiO2-650(R, A) and TiO2-750(R, A) samples. 2.3 Activity measurements The hydrogenation of aqueous levulinic acid was performed in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (10 mm id, 420 mm length) in a down-flow mode. About 0.1 g of catalyst (−18/+25 sieved particles) was placed in between two quartz wool plugs in the middle of the reactor. The catalyst was reduced at 500 °C for 3 h in H2 at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1. After reduction, the catalyst sample was brought to the desired reaction temperature (260 °C) and the aqueous LA (10 wt%) was fed at a flow rate of 1.0 mL h−1 along with a H2 flow rate of 30 mL min−1 using a syringe feed pump (M/s. B. Braun, Germany). Mass flow controllers (Alicat Scientific make) were employed to monitor the gas flow rates. For each 1 h, the product mixture was collected in an ice trap and analyzed using GC-MS (QP5050A Shimadzu) and a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890 A GC equipped with an EB capillary wax column and an FID detector) and 1,4-dioxane was used an internal standard. The products were also confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy [Fig. S2]. The reactor outlet was connected to a GC-TCD (thermal conductivity detector), and no COx (x = 1 and/or 2) products were identified. The carbon depositions on the used catalysts were found to be less than 0.5% and the carbon mass balance is > 99%, unless otherwise mentioned. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Different characterization techniques were employed in order to rationalize the surface and bulk properties of these catalysts by using BET-SA, powder XRD, H2-TPR, H2-TPD, NH3-TPD, XPS, Raman spectroscopy, EPR, UV-DRS, CO pulse chemisorption, SEM, TEM-HAADF, ICP-OES and CHNS analyses. To avoid the self-plagiarism, all the experimental details related to the above techniques are mentioned in ESI. 3 Results 3.1 Powder XRD analysis The diffraction patterns obtained from X-ray analysis of calcined fresh 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-550(A,R), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-650(R,A), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-750(R,A), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 samples indicated diffraction peaks attributed to the NiO phase, with peaks appeared at 2θ = 37.2° and 43.2° ( Fig. 1a) [ICDD # 78–0429]. The Ni impregnated on the as-synthesized TiO2-A calcined from 550° to 750°C showed both anatase and rutile peaks. Only anatase in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and just rutile phase in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) (along with NiO peaks were present in both) hereafter these samples are called as 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) respectively. From these patterns, it is clearly noticed that the anatase phase was slowly diminished with an increase in calcination temperature of TiO2 up to 750 °C and is absent at 800 °C with emergence of sharp rutile signals (Fig. 1a iii-vi). Overall, these normalized patterns showed weak diffraction lines of NiO phase compared to the TiO2 phase. The intensities of the peaks due to rutile phase became sharp with increase in calcination temperature of TiO2-500(A). After reduction at 500 °C, these samples showed solely metallic Ni phase at 2θ = 44.5° and 52° (ICDD # 04–0850) in all the samples along with prominent anatase and rutile peaks (Fig. 1b). Traces of anatase peaks are still found in TiO2 calcined at 750 °C, but completely disappeared in the sample calcined at 800 °C. The peaks appearing at 25.5, 48.1 and 62.76° are ascribed to the TiO2-anatase phase [JCPDS No. 21–1272] found only in TiO2-500(A) both in fresh and reduced samples [8]. Diffraction lines due to rutile peaks are appeared at 2θ = 27.5°, 36.1°, 54.5° [JCPDS no. 21–1276] and the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 shows the main diffraction signals at 25.5° (anatase) and 27.5° (rutile) (Fig. 1b ii-vi). All the diffraction signals can be assigned to either the anatase phase or rutile phase, and the observation did not reveal any other peaks related to titania. The crystallite size of nickel is increased due to a minimize in surface area of the TiO2 probably because of anatase phase underwent transformation to the rutile phase upon calcination from 550 to 800 °C (Table S2). As observed from the XRD patterns, anatase (101) and rutile (110) are the most intense and exposed facets of the respective TiO2 phase. The anatase peaks are slightly broader than the FWHM of the peaks corresponding to the rutile phase. 3.2 Raman spectroscopic analysis The Raman spectra of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) samples are displayed in Fig. 2. The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) sample exhibited stretching vibrations at 141, 425 and 610 cm−1, which correspond to the B1g, Eg and A1g symmetries, respectively (Fig. 2a). The broad band seen near 254 cm−1 is ascribed to O-O interactions involving three- and four-coordinate oxygen [15]. The Ni supported on TiO2-500(A) and TiO2-P25 (Fig. 2b, c) showed the Eg band, which is a result of O-Ti-O symmetric stretching vibrations observed at 151 and 630 cm−1. The B1g band appeared at 393 cm−1, which is attributed to the symmetric bending vibration of O-Ti-O, and the antisymmetric bending vibration occurred at 510 cm−1 that corresponds to the A1g band [31]. These results indicated a clear distinction between the anatase and rutile forms of TiO2 present in the catalysts (Fig. 2). In the presence of the rutile phase (Fig. 2b), band intensities due to the anatase phase are suppressed in the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 sample. Furthermore, the relative peak intensities of the anatase phase were almost diminished in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), which is in good correlation with XRD analyses wherein the anatase diffraction peak intensities are decreased by the occurrence of intensified rutile peaks (Fig. 1b vi). 3.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The reduction characteristics of 10 wt%Ni supported on TiO2-500(A), TiO2-800(R) and TiO2-P25 catalysts was analyzed by H2-TPR ( Fig. 3). The H2 consumptions are reported in ( Table 1) and extent of reduction is presented in SI (Fig. S1 and Table S3). The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) showed reduction of NiO around 500 °C predominantly, with a small peak at 340 °C (Fig. 3a). The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 sample displayed two-stage reduction profiles with a weak reduction signal and an intense peak at 525 °C was observed (Fig. 3b). In contrast, the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) sample showed a broad reduction peak centered around 390 °C with a small hump at 500 °C. It is unlikely to discard the partial reduction of TiO2 that is expected at high temperatures to form oxygen vacancy sites such as Ti+3-Ov [17]. These patterns clearly indicated that nickel oxide particles got reduced at low temperature which are interacted with rutile phase of TiO2. On the contrary, the Tmax was found to be high for NiO when it interacted with anatase TiO2. More than 95% of the nickel oxide present in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) was reduced below 450 °C. Conversely, NiO/TiO2-500(A) and NiO/TiO2-P25 catalysts were reduced at and above 500 °C to a large extent. The low temperature peak around 390 °C appeared in Ni/TiO2-P25 is probably caused by the reduction of NiO interacting with the rutile TiO2 phase [22]. The variation in the reduction maxima of NiO particles on different phases of titania could be due to the different degree of interaction between the nickel and the TiO2 or a high degree of hydrogen spillover occurring on the Ni/TiO2-800(R) sample [13]. 3.4 X-ray photo electron spectroscopy The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) fresh samples are presented in Fig. 4. The Ni 2 P spectra of both 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) shows 2p3/2 signal at 855.4 and 2p1/2 at 872.7 eV which are in consistent with the earlier reports [14]. The accompanying satellite peaks at 861.9 and 879.2 eV indicate that NiO species are present at the near surface region (Fig. 4a). The peaks associated to Ti (2p3/2) and Ti (2p1/2) seen at 458.83 and 464.6 eV for 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 458.71 and 464.5 eV for 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) respectively, indicate the presence of Ti+4 species (Fig. 4b). The different Ti-Ti and Ti-O distances in the anatase and rutile forms of TiO2 may be a possible reason for a small change in the binding energy. The O 1 s spectra of 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) show a sharp peak at 529.6 eV, with additional shoulder peaks detected at 531.7 and 533.1 eV (Fig. 4c i). The weak signal at higher BE may originate from surface OH groups which is absent in the rutile TiO2 supported Ni catalyst that exhibited a sharp O 1 s peak centered at 529.6 eV [32], while the FTIR spectra of these catalysts exhibited weak signal due to –OH group in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) compared to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst (SI, Fig. S13). 3.5 UV-DRS analysis The UVDR spectra of the TiO2-500(A), TiO2-P25 and TiO2-800(R) samples are reported in Fig. S3i. The spectra show two prominent bands at 230 and 310 nm. The fresh 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts showed similar absorption bands to those that appeared in the bare supports, which originated from O → Ti charge transitions (O2p to Ti3d) (Fig. S3ii). The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) (Fig. S3iiic) showed a bathochromic shift (310–355 nm), which is explained by the presence of larger Ni particles compared to the nickel present in both the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 catalysts [33]. The band at 720 nm represents the octahedral Ni2+ species in the NiO lattice (Fig. S3ii a, b, c). This band is absent in the reduced samples (Fig. S3iii) indicating the complete reduction of Ni2+ species into metallic Ni, which is in good correlation with XRD analysis [34]. 3.6 NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) The strength and distribution of acid sites on the catalyst surface was estimated by NH3-TPD analysis ( Fig. 5), and the NH3 uptakes of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25, 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) samples are presented in Table 1. Nature of the acid sites are either Bronsted or Lewis or both but TiO2 encompasses more of Lewis acidity than the Bronsted acidity [18]. However, the surface ionic nickel species would act as Lewis acid centers, and their strength may be lower than the other transition metal oxides when the surface nickel is partially reduced, though in this case, NH3-TPD was analyzed after a reductive pretreatment. Both 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) showed an intense NH3 desorption peak at 165 °C along with weak signals at 630 and 700 °C. Quite interestingly, the low temperature peak (165 °C) is absent in the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst (Fig. 5a). On the other hand, the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) displayed signals assigned to strong acid sites in the temperature region 600–750 °C. More than 90% of sites represent weak to medium strength over Ni supported on anatase and P25 catalysts. Although relatively weak signals are found with the rutile TiO2-supported nickel catalyst, those are very strong acid sites. There is a peak shift towards high temperatures found over 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 catalyst as the peak tail extended up to 450 °C. This is presumably due to a certain portion of TiO2 in the rutile phase in P25. 3.7 Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis The EPR signals present in the fresh calcined samples are found to be weak (Fig. S4). These signals originated from the electrons trapped by oxygen vacancies present in TiO2 crystal. Calcination of TiO2-500(A) at high temperature (800 °C) led to the generation of oxygen vacancies; consequently, high intensity signals were observed at low field over the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst. The ‘g′ values of ca. 1.992, 1.964 and 1.980, 1.945 are assigned to Ti+3 species present in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), respectively [35]. In the reduced catalysts, the signal at "g" is equivalent to 2.2, which is attributed to metallic Ni (Fig. S5). The following equation demonstrates the relationship between the line width ΔHpp (ΔHpp = peak-to-peak width) of the EPR signal and the particle size of a nanoparticle, where “a” is the proportionality constant, “d” is the particle size in nm, and ΔHpp is the line width of the ESR signal in mT, and. d = a(ΔHpp)0·5 The proportionality constant for nickel was found to be "1.2" [36]. The peak to peak width of the Ni(0) signal is observed to be high in the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst (Fig. S5) relative to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 catalysts at ca. 200, 152 and 172 mT, respectively. Though the Ni(0) particle size measured from EPR and XRD analyses are slightly varied, the trends are similar for these catalysts (Table 1). 3.8 SEM and TEM analysis The morphological features of the TiO2-500(A), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts were elucidated by scanning electron microscopy (Fig. S6- S8). Smaller particles with a uniform size distribution can be observed on both 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts. To gain more insights in to the morphology of Ni particles on anatase and rutile TiO2 surfaces, TEM analysis is performed ( Fig. 6). It shows that the Ni particles are in an irregular shape over the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) and flat and raft-like nickel particles on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst (Fig. 6a-d). These images show nucleation of nickel on TiO2 is occurred in different way as the shapes of nickel particles are varied with change in crystal phase. This is explained by a higher interfacial energy for Ni/TiO2-anatase than for Ni/TiO2-rutile. From the environmental TEM analysis of the in-situ reduced Ni/TiO2-anatase and Ni/TiO2-rutile samples, Li et al. reported that Ni nanoparticles nucleate both on rutile and anatase supports [37]. The nickel particles are mostly flat on anatase surface and evidence of raft-like nickel clusters are seen (Fig. 6i). Sort of nickel plateaus are clearly visible on the rutile surface which couldn’t be seen on the anatase TiO2. Furthermore, the growth of nickel nanoparticles is three-dimensional on the anatase and in a two-dimensional structure on the rutile TiO2 surface with Ni plateaus (Fig. 6c, d, j). The average Ni particle size on rutile and anatase TiO2 surfaces are found to be 20.0 and 14.6 nm (Fig. 6), and the corresponding histograms are shown in SI (Fig. S10), which are in a close range when compared to the particle size measured by XRD and EPR analyses (Table 1). The lattice fringes observed with a plane distance of 0.201 nm are typical of the (111) plane and can be inferred due to Ni particles that are oriented along the (111) crystallographic direction. The SAED (selected area electron diffraction) patterns of 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) (Fig. 6k) shows that the TiO2-500(A) is in the polycrystalline, while in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) (Fig. 6e), the particles are mostly single-crystalline in nature [38]. The high angle annular dark field (HAADF) images (Fig. 6f, l) indicated the distribution of Ni, Ti, and O elements present in the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) samples (Fig. 6m-t). 3.9 Activity studies Levulinic acid hydrogenation has been carried out at 260 °C and the results are presented in Table 2. In the absence of nickel, the bare TiO2-500(A), TiO2-P25 and TiO2-800(R) displayed a LA conversion of 5%, 2%, and 0.7% respectively, with 100% selectivity towards angelica lactones, i.e., the LA dehydration products such as α-AL and β-AL in almost equal proportions with 50% selectivity each ( Scheme 1). Obviously, no hydrogenation products such as GVL and VA was expected because of the fact that Ni was absent. The Ni impregnated on the TiO2 calcined at 500 °C (10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A)) catalyst demonstrated a low LA conversion ∼7.5% with selectivity of angelica lactones ∼ 36.6% (α- about 29.4 and β- 7.2%) and 54.3% of GVL, indicating the role of nickel that could convert the ALs in to GVL. While the Ni doped on high temperature calcined TiO2 supports (550–750 °C i.e., 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-550(A, R), 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-650(R, A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-750(R, A) showed that the LA conversion is linearly increased from 7.5% to 90.3%, conversely the selectivity of α-AL, β-AL are decreased and the GVL selectivity is increased from 54.3% to 95% ( Fig. 7). The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) (TiO2 calcined at 800 °C that exhibited pure rutile TiO2 along with nickel diffraction lines) showed tremendously high LA conversion of about 92.6% with a GVL rate of 245 × 10−6 moles (gcat)−1 s−1 when compared to other catalysts. In the comparative analysis, anatase TiO2 supported Ni exhibited a meagre GVL rate of 11 × 10−6 mole (gcat)−1 s−1. The TiO2-P25 (Degussa) supported Ni catalyst has been examined under similar conditions that showed slightly improved LA conversion of 15.7%, with an almost similar range of selectivity towards ALs, GVL and VA as compared to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst. The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-A-commercial catalyst showed 9.8% LA conversion with α-AL (39.6%) and a GVL selectivity of 60.4%. These results indicated that nickel interacting with rutile TiO2 demonstrated enhanced LA conversion as well as GVL selectivity when compared to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 catalysts (Table 2). In order to rationalize the role of the rutile phase of TiO2 for Ni, we have examined (under similar experimental conditions) the varied ratios of physically mixed 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts with proportions of 3:1, 1:1, and 1:3 (by weight ratio), respectively, for the hydrogenation of LA ( Fig. 8). The activity data on these physically mixed catalysts revealed that both the LA conversion and GVL selectivity increased with an increase in the loading of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst. To avoid ambiguity, the catalytic activities on these physically mixed catalysts are replicated for the LA hydrogenation, and the precision levels are within a 5% range in terms of LA conversion and product selectivity (Table S4). The higher rate of GVL over rutile TiO2 supported Ni was rationalized based on the physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts. At a reaction temperature of 260 °C, the LA hydrogenation measurements showed that the 5 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst displayed a more or less similar rate of GVL formation compared to 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A). While the 15 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) demonstrated improved LA conversion (41%), as well as selectivity towards GVL (88%), when compared to 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst. Whereas the 5 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst exhibited lower GVL rates compared to the 10 and 15 wt%Ni/ TiO2-800(R) catalysts. A marginal improvement in LA conversion was observed over 15 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst with a small decrease in GVL selectivity (Table 2). On the other hand, the 5 wt%Ni/TiO2 – 800(R) catalyst exhibited better performance than all the various Ni (5, 10, 15 wt%) supported on TiO2-500(A) catalysts. While the TiO2-500(A) calcined at different temperature from 550° to 750°C (TiO2-550(A, R); TiO2-650(R, A) and TiO2-750(R, A)); none of these supports showed formation of the GVL or VA, except the angelica lactones with varied proportions, which is obviously due to the absence of nickel (Table S5). The effect of reaction temperature on the TiO2-500(A) and TiO2-800(R) supported Ni catalysts was studied at 270 °C (Table 2). Upon increasing the reaction temperature to 270 °C, the LA conversion was found to be 17.6% with slightly improved selectivity towards GVL (66.4%) over the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst. Further increase in reaction temperature to 280 °C; both the LA conversion and GVL selectivity were found to be higher than the catalyst tested at 260 °C. (Table 2). In contrast, the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst showed a decrease in GVL selectivity at 270 °C. This is probably due to the further conversion of GVL to VA occurring at 270 °C. The CHNS analysis confirmed the deposition of a small amount of carbon on both 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts recovered after 24 h of run (Table S6). 4 Discussion Nickel nanoparticles that interact with the anatase and rutile phases of TiO2 represent different degrees of defect sites due to the difference in the orientation of the anatase and rutile space groups, and such defect sites play a significant role in the catalytic process. From the DFT study, Hinuma et al. reported that the catalytic performance of metal oxides can be unraveled from the energy required to remove oxygen from a surface to form O vacancy sites and the activation of hydrogen on such sites for the catalytic hydrogenation reactions [39,40]. According to them, the energy required for the oxygen vacancy sites on rutile TiO2 is lower than that for anatase TiO2. Many studies have shown the typical behavior of nickel when it interacts with different phases of TiO2 for the hydrogenation of CO2 [41], hydrodeoxygenation of m-cresol [42], and methanation of COx (x = 1 and/or 2) [43]. These studies revealed that the catalytic activity and selectivity of Ni-based systems are entirely different when different crystal phases of TiO2 are used as a support. Some efforts have been made for the measurement of the catalytic activity of Ni supported on TiO2 (anatase and rutile) for the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol [44] and CO2 methanation [39]. However, synthesis of GVL using biomass derived levulinic acid conversion is not yet reported over Ni supported on different crystal phases such as anatase and/or rutile. Here we found a high intrinsic activity in the LA conversion with a GVL rate of 257 × 10−6 mol (gcat)−1 s−1 over 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), which is 20 times higher than on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst. It is interesting to note that the physically mixed catalysts showed improved LA conversion as well as the GVL selectivity with an increase in rutile phase composition (Fig. 8). A similar trend is observed with the TiO2-A calcined at higher temperatures ranging from 550° to 800°C which showed an increase in rutile phase composition with incremental calcination temperature. The rutile phase composition of these catalysts is determined according to the formula proposed by Spurr and Myer [45]. A plot of GVL rates against the rutile phase composition present in the TiO2 (subjected to different calcination temperatures) supported Ni catalyst is reported in Fig. 9. With an increase in rutile phase composition, GVL rates are linearly increased, indicating the self-consistency of our analysis, where the GVL rates are analogous to the physically mixed catalysts. The hydrogenation of LA activities over the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts are distinctly varied. According to Messou et al., there are implications associated with using CO as a probe molecule to estimate the nickel metal dispersions, particularly in the case of Ni/TiO2 catalysts, due to the migration of titania on the nickel surface [39]. The CO pulse chemisorption studies indicated that a little higher nickel dispersion was observed on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) (0.66%) compared to 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) (0.56%) catalysts (Table 1). The strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) is a known phenomenon, between partially reducible oxide supports such as TiO2 [46] and nickel [47] when they are subjected to high temperature reductive-treatments. The Ni particle size measured from the CO uptakes on both the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalysts is found to be very high when compared to the Ni particle size measured by TEM analysis (Fig. S10). This discrepancy can be understood from the TiOx overlayer coverage on both the anatase and rutile TiO2 supported Ni catalysts. However, the TEM analysis showed a high ratio of TiOx overlayers on the surface of the Ni supported on anatase TiO2 and, to a lesser extent, on rutile TiO2. The CO pulse chemisorption data showed a slightly higher CO uptake (0.254 cm3/g) over 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) than on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst (0.217 cm3/g), suggesting a little higher exposure of nickel on the surface of the rutile TiO2, although the surface area of rutile is four times less than the anatase. A very low CO uptake on both the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalysts reflects the large size Ni particles when compared to the average Ni particle size measured by TEM analysis (Fig. S10). This is understood from the TiOx overlayers coverage on Ni particles [39]. While correlated to the Ni particle size in terms of the catalytic performance of these catalysts, 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) performed better than the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst because of the fact that the nickel particles are largely covered by TiOx overlayers on anatase TiO2 compared to the rutile support, which is further supported by a lower CO uptake over 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst, and the Ni particle size obviously manifested to be high. Furthermore, the TEM-HAADF results ascertained the partial coverage of Ni by TiOx overlayers on rutile supported Ni catalyst, and a large extent of TiOx overlayers are found on Ni/TiO2-anatase catalyst. Therefore, it is difficult to correlate the role of Ni particle size on catalytic performance while the Ni particle size was measured by CO pulse chemisorption in parenthesis with the TEM data, particularly in the case of Ni supported on TiO2 (anatase and/or rutile) catalysts for the hydrogenation of LA, as TiOx overlayer formation is inevitable. Furthermore, the SMSI effect could change the geometry of the particle and the overall dispersion of surface nickel. However, we found a lower CO uptake on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst compared to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst (Table 1). It was reported that during the catalyst preparation, a small amount of TiO2 may be dissolved in the impregnation solution, and such species will be deposited on the surface of Ni particles during the reduction process [48]. Such phenomena can be validated only when the catalyst preparation techniques (impregnation, precipitation, or deposition-precipitation) and the extent of titania dissolution in the nickel precursor solution with varied pHs are investigated. However, from the environmental-TEM analysis of the both anatase and rutile TiO2 supported Ni catalysts, Li et al. proved that the SMSI effect was occurring to a small extent rather what has been said by Raupp et al. [37]. Nevertheless, the high-resolution TEM-HAADF images indicated a partial coverage of TiOx overlayers on Ni/TiO2-800(R) and a thin layer of TiOx coverage on the Ni/TiO2-500(A) sample (Fig. 6c, j), which was also seen in the elemental mapping of these samples (6 m, 6 n, and 6q, 6r). The TPD of NH3 further supports this observation, as the NH3 uptake was four times higher on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst compared to the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst, complimenting a higher coverage of TiOx on the nickel surface of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst, and contributing to enhanced acidity (Table 1). The other reason for the higher acidity on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst may also be due to a higher surface area of TiO2(A) than the TiO2(R). Apart from these, isolated Ni patches are observed on both the Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) surfaces; in contrast, protruding particles with plateaus of nickel islands are seen only in the rutile supported Ni catalyst. The protruding Ni particles are partially covered with TiOx overlayers (Fig. 6c) in 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R), while a thin layer of Ni is surrounded by TiOx around the Ni particle on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) (Fig. 6j). This could be explained further from the H2-TPR patterns, which illustrated a high temperature reduction of nickel particles on anatase TiO2 compared to rutile TiO2 supported nickel and the reduction of such TiOx species requires higher temperatures than the reduction of surface exposed nickel oxide particles (Fig. 3). The X-ray photoelectron spectra (Fig. 4c) also revealed that the oxygen is in different environments at the near surface region of the Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst [49]. The first step in LA hydrogenation is the formation of angelica lactones, which is facilitated by surface acidic sites [50]. The adsorption of β-AL is more facile than the adsorption of α-AL on the Ni surface. A higher percentage of α-AL than β-AL is explained by the relatively less steric hindrance of the double (present in β-AL compared to α-AL) adsorption on the Ni metal site for its reduction to form GVL (Scheme 1, Table 2). The pure supports showed only the dehydration product, i.e., angelica lactones. Earlier, we reported the LA hydrogenation over bulk NiO catalyst that showed high selectivity towards GVL (98%) though the LA conversion was very low [16]. And the catalysts tested without reduction behaved like support materials in both catalysts (10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R)), demonstrating the formation of angelica lactones only (Table 2 c); which is explained by the absence of metallic nickel that activates the hydrogen and reduces the double bond present in the angelica lactones (Scheme 1). Reductive pre-treatment has some significance on the catalytic activity and product selectivity. When the catalysts reduced at 350 °C/3 h; the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) showed 4% LA conversion with a high ratio of both ALs (α-, β-) of about 56% and GVL selectivity of 44%. In contrast, 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) demonstrated improved LA conversion and GVL selectivity of 98% when the catalyst was reduced at 350 °C without the formation of ALs (Table 2 d). The absence of ALs suggests that the reductive pretreatment at 350 °C could be ideal to achieve the best GVL yields. These results indicate that reductive pretreatment has a strong influence on the selective hydrogenation activity of Ni/TiO2 catalysts for the production of GVL, a valuable fuel additive. Cui et al. also demonstrated the importance of reductive pretreatment during the hydrodeoxygenation of m-cresol over Ni/TiO2 catalysts [42]. The product distribution acquired with these catalysts showed the formation of valeric acid (VA) of about 9–10% over 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-P25 and less than 3% on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst. Needless to say, VA has equal importance as it can also be used as a fuel additive. Formation of VA occurs through the ring-opening of GVL through β-proton abstraction on the surface Bronsted acid sites [51]. The 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst showed a little higher VA selectivity than the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst, which can be explained by the presence of a surface -OH group, which was visible in the O 1 s spectra of the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst, appeared at a BE of 531–532.5 eV as a shoulder peak (Fig. 4c) [32]. Formation of VA can also be explained due to the hetero-junctions on the surface, sort of Ni0/Niδ+ species may be formed due to surface heterogeneity which was seen in TEM-HAADF results as the TiOx overlayers covered on the nickel particles on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst. This observation is further supported by the H2-TPR results, wherein the reduction maximum was extended beyond 500 °C on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst and such hetero-junctions may prevail on the catalyst surface while nickel particles are in close proximity to TiOx species [52]. The TEM-HAADF indicated that the spots of TiOx overlayers are high, and a major portion of Ni was encapsulated and only a small portion of surface Ni remained exposed over the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst (Fig. 6n, r). While the partially covered TiOx overlayers were found with 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst (Fig. 6m-r). Messou et al. investigated the hydrogen spillover on Ni supported on both anatase and rutile TiO2. Based on the H2-TPD studies, they concluded that the hydrogen spillover was higher over Ni supported on rutile TiO2-R than on the anatase TiO2 catalyst [39,53]. To establish the hydrogen spillover effect, we have performed the H2-TPD of these catalysts and the patterns are reported in Fig. 10. The H2 desorption peak starts at 100 °C on the rutile supported Ni, while it is at 150 °C for the Ni/TiO2-500(A). In the comparative analysis, H2-TPD showed that the H2 uptake was 3.7 times higher on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) than on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) catalyst, demonstrating a strong hydrogen spillover phenomenon. The Tmax for H2 desorption on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts were 218 and 277 °C respectively. The amount of H2 desorbed on these catalysts is found to be 3.0 × 10−6 moles (gcat)−1 and 11 × 10−6 moles (gcat)−1 for 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) and 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalysts respectively. The H2-TPD patterns showed the desorption signals for both 10 wt%Ni supported on TiO2-500(A) and TiO2-800(R) samples which was below ∼450 °C. However, such signals are believed to be weakly adsorbed H2 or decomposition of subsurface NiHx species [54]. A lower rate of H2 spillover on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-500(A) is explained by a high ratio of nickel particles covered by TiOx; consequently, a lower CO uptake was also observed (Table 1). This could be the reason why a higher rate of angelica lactones was formed on Ni supported anatase TiO2 and the reverse is the case for the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) catalyst. Due to the difference in crystal morphology and also the variation in the surface area of the TiO2, patchy Ni particles on anatase that protrude as well as isolated Ni clusters are seen on the rutile surface, which were reduced at low temperatures and consequently obtained with an improved GVL. 5 Conclusions The as-synthesized TiO2 when subjected to calcination from 500° to 800°C produced anatase, rutile and a mixer of these two phases depends upon the temperature applied. Raman shifts are quite distinctly noticed based on their phase (anatase, rutile or a mixture of these) composition and their relative ratios. The nickel supported on these supports emphasized that rutile TiO2 was suggested to be a preferable support for Ni in the selective conversion of levulinic acid to γ-valerolactone, a valuable fuel additive. In the absence of Ni, the pure supports did show some activity for the conversion of LA to angelica lactones only and GVL and valeric acid were not found. Transformation of anatase to rutile occurred during high temperature calcination, which had a pronounced effect on the hydrogenation activity of Ni/TiO2 catalysts. Based on the surface and bulk properties of these catalysts, it is summarized that the TiO2-R is a desirable support for Ni in the selective hydrogenation of LA to GVL attributed to its ease of reduction, hydrogen spillover, higher CO uptake and lower acidity of the catalyst. Unlike the TiO2-A which showed a shift in reduction of NiO species to higher temperatures in H2-TPR pattern due to the encapsulation of Ni particles by TiOx overlayers (TEM-HAADF results), lower CO uptake and higher acidity of the support responsible for predominant formation of angelica lactones and suppressed hydrogenation activity to form GVL. coredata.dc:description: Rutile TiO2 was identified as a suitable support for nickel than the anatase form in the selective conversion of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) with a 20-fold rate enhancement. TEM-HAADF results revealed a high degree of Ni encapsulation by titania species on the anatase that resulted in lower LA conversion with a high selectivity of angelica lactones. While nickel plateaus with protruding particles partially covered by TiOx overlayers on a rutile surface was the reason for the higher rate of GVL. CO chemisorption results indicated a lower uptake on 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-anatase than on the 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-rutile catalyst and a high rate of hydrogen spillover was manifested by rutile TiO2 supported Ni catalyst than its counterpart anatase. Variations in the crystal phase of TiO2 and their interaction with nickel could substantially influence the GVL formation. High intrinsic activity of 10 wt%Ni/TiO2-800(R) was explained and discussed using surface and bulk characteristics of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Rutile TiO2 a desirable support for Ni catalyst in the synthesis of γ-valerolactone: Influence of titania crystal phase on the product distribution
